p: I had a real Enat letter for breakfast this morning, and yours, Oddie, is already several days old. Mighty glad for both.

It has taken a little time to bore in here, but I'm almost in there now, and if I were sticking around much longer, it would become a really happy experience. Things have been going very well, and better and better lately. They're discovering the fact that I'm a "human bean" (as Ben would put it), and it is true that young people get way under my skin. So much about to happen to them that they can't suspect - and they so eager about it! I'm all for them. I spiel about three times a day - sometimes four; and there are occasional dinners & luncheons to be eaten, with some sips of

4 o'clock tea. I had to talk to Rotary at the Galesburg Club yesterday - a large & unusually mature group of really fine men. I liked them, and I've heard they liked me. I feel pink & didn't want to do the job, but the feel of them awakened me.

The other day I had an English class, and my purpose was to induce the young hushies to realize that poetry is not effeminate. That had been their coulention, and the Prof. (a fine, sensitive lady) tipped me off & asked me to woek on them with the objection in mind. I thook them in the flank & rear! Began by asking if they had felt so, & got a frank admission. Then I told them I was glad they felt so; but, as it turned out, there was something else to say; and by indirection I lead them to a point where they actually admitted that they saw differently.
It's the honesty and eagerness of such young people that move me. They are actually frank when questioned.

I was with the Adelphi fraternity (.journalism, literature) last evening. Among other things I told them that rather funny Indian story about how young High Horse won his girl. They had supposed Indians were always serious and sort of dumb!
My cold is in my chest - not sore, but a breath-taker. The weather is soft & muggy. That's what's the chief trouble.
It gives me real happiness to think of you two really happy together. People claw their way hysterically through a whole life time trying to "get" something, and so
utterly miss being it. It's pitiful & fainly silly. Surely it's living that matters.

But since you have the best thing, Ollie, one of these times you will find the opportunity & the desire to write something good. There's a quality - and a slant - in you letters that should be real assets in creative writing. I do believe you can do a very human novel.
If we just had a chunk of money for a good farm ranch combination! By gosh, we'd do some sane living. Who knows? It's an illogical world and doesn't seem to care what happens. Maybe that will happen.
